title: 112_hr3012
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" and includes a numerical limitation to any single foreign state. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to make changes to section 202(a)(2), including adjustments to subsections and numerical values. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to make changes to section 202(a)(2), including adjustments to subsections and numerical values. Subsection (a)(3) is modified by striking references to section 203(a) and subsection (a)(5) is removed. Subsection (e) is amended to address visa allotments for countries exceeding the numerical limitation specified in subsection (a)(2). The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allocate visa numbers to natives of specific countries under section 203(a) in a proportional manner. Additionally, the Chinese Student Protection Act of 1992 is amended to remove a subsection and make adjustments to visa allotments for countries exceeding numerical limitations. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change subsections (a) and (d), with an effective date of September 30, 2011. Transition rules for employment-based immigrants are outlined in subsection (e). For fiscal years 2012 and 2013, a percentage of immigrant visas will be allotted to natives of foreign states with lower numbers of immigrants in previous years under the Immigration and Nationality Act. For fiscal year 2013 and 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas will be allotted to natives of foreign states with lower numbers of immigrants in previous years under the Immigration and Nationality Act. In fiscal year 2013 and 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas will be allocated to natives of foreign states with lower numbers of immigrants in previous years under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Natives of a foreign state or dependent area not among the top two states with the highest number of natives obtaining immigrant visas in fiscal year 2012 are subject to per-country visa limits. The number of reserved visas for each foreign state or area in a fiscal year cannot exceed 25 percent for a single state or 2 percent overall. In fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, a maximum of 85 percent of unreserved immigrant visas under certain sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act shall be allotted to natives of any single foreign state to prevent unused visas. In fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, a special rule allows for the issuance of immigrant visas under certain sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act if the total number of visas available would otherwise not be issued. Section 202(b) of the Act applies in determining the foreign state to which an alien is chargeable. The House of Representatives passed the bill on November 29, 2011. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
